Imraan.wiki_summary: Imran in Islam is regarded as the father of Mary (mother of Jesus)

Hud.wiki_summary: Hud was a prophet of ancient Arabia mentioned in the Qur’an

Aal-Imraan.wiki_summary: Imran in Islam is regarded as the father of Mary (mother of Jesus)

Qana.wiki_summary: Qana, also spelled Cana or Kana, (Arabic: قانا‎) is a village in southern Lebanon located 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) southeast of the city of Tyre and 12 kilometres (7.5 mi) north of the border with Israel.

Assam.wiki_summary: Assam (, Assamese: [ɔxɔm] (listen)) is a state in northeastern India, situated south of the eastern Himalayas along the Brahmaputra and Barak River valleys.

Erithria.wiki_summary: officially the State of Eritrea, is a sovereign state in the Horn of Africa, with its capital at Asmara

Chechnia.wiki_summary: Chechnya, officially the Chechen Republic is a federal subject (a republic) of Russia.

Crusaders.wiki_summary: The crusades were a series of religious wars in western Asia and Europe initiated, supported and sometimes directed by the Roman Catholic Church between the 11th and the 17th century.

Mujahid.wiki_summary: Mujahideen (Arabic: مجاهدين‎ mujāhidīn) is the plural form of mujahid (Arabic: مجاهد‎), the term for one engaged in Jihad (literally, “struggle”).

Mujahideen.wiki_summary: Mujahideen (Arabic: مجاهدين‎ mujāhidīn) is the plural form of mujahid (Arabic: مجاهد‎), the term for one engaged in Jihad (literally, “struggle”).

Allahu Akbar.wiki_summary: The Takbīr (تَكْبِير, Arabic pronunciation: [tækˈbiːr]) is the Arabic phrase Allāhu akbar (الله أكبر), usually translated as "God is [the] greatest".

Patron.wiki_summary: The word "patron" derives from the Latin: patronus ("patron"), one who gives benefits to his clients (see Patronage in ancient Rome)

Riyal.wiki_summary: The Saudi riyal is the currency of Saudi Arabia

Shawwaal.wiki_summary: Shawwāl is the tenth month of the lunar based Islamic calendar

Muharram.wiki_summary: Muḥarram (Arabic: المحرّم) is the first month of the Islamic calendar.

Halal.wiki_summary: Halal (; Arabic: حلال‎ ḥalāl), also spelled hallal or halaal, is an Arabic word that translates to "permissible" into English.

Haram.wiki_summary: Haram (; Arabic: حَرَام‎ ḥarām [ħaˈraːm]) is an Arabic term meaning forbidden.

Exalted.wiki_summary: Exalted is a role-playing game published by White Wolf Publishing.

Shari'a.wiki_summary: Sharia (, Arabic: شريعة‎ [ʃaˈriːʕa]), Islamic law or sharia law is a religious law forming part of the Islamic tradition

infidels.wiki_summary: Infidel (literally "unfaithful") is a term used in certain religions for those accused of unbelief in the central tenets of their own religion, for members of another religion, or for the irreligious.

Mushrik.wiki_summary: In Islam, shirk (Arabic: شرك‎ širk) is the sin of idolatry or polytheism, i.e., the deification or worship of anyone or anything besides God, i.e., Allah.

Al-Ma'ida.wiki_summary: Al Māʼidah (Arabic: المائدة‎, "The Table" or "The Table Spread with Food", likely a word of Ethiopic origin) is the fifth chapter (sūrah) of the Quran, with 120 verses (āyāt).

Fatawa.wiki_summary: A fatwā (, also US: ; Arabic: فتوى‎; plural fatāwā فتاوى) is a nonbinding legal opinion on a point of Islamic law (sharia) given by a qualified jurist in response to a question posed by a private individual, judge or government

Jihad.wiki_summary: Jihad (English: ; Arabic: جهاد‎ jihād [dʒɪˈhaːd]) is an Arabic word which literally means striving or struggling, especially with a praiseworthy aim.

Sunnah.wiki_summary: Sunnah (Arabic: سُنَّة‎, sunnah, plural Arabic: سُنَن‎ sunan [sunan]), also sunna or sunnat, is the body of literature which discusses and prescribes the traditional customs and practices of the Islamic community, both social and legal,[1] often but not necessarily based on the verbally transmitted record of the teachings, deeds and sayings, silent permissions (or disapprovals) of the Islamic prophet Muhammad, as well as various reports about Muhammad's companions.

Ahlul-Sunnah.wiki_summary: So Ahlus-Sunnah wa'l-Jama'ah have been described with sticking to the Sunnah and [in all circumstances] avoiding / disregarding the invented matters and innovations in the Din (religion)

Rashidoon.wiki_summary: The Rashidun Caliphs (Rightly Guided Caliphs; Arabic: الخلفاء الراشدون‎ al-Khulafāʾu ar-Rāshidūn), often simply called, collectively, "the Rashidun", is a term used in Sunni Islam to refer to the 30-year reign of the first four caliphs (successors) following the death of the Islamic prophet Muhammad, namely: Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman ibn Affan, and Ali of the Rashidun Caliphate, the first caliphate

Imams.wiki_summary: Imam (/ɪˈmɑːm/; Arabic: إمام‎ imām; plural: أئمة aʼimmah) is an Islamic leadership position

Riba.wiki_summary: Riba (Arabic: ربا ,الربا، الربٰوة‎ ribā or al-ribā, IPA: [ˈrɪbæː]) can be roughly translated as "usury", or unjust, exploitative gains made in trade or business under Islamic law.

Baqarah.wiki_summary: Al-Baqarah (Arabic: البقرة‎, "The Heifer" or "The Cow") is the second and longest chapter (sūrah) of the Quran.

SWT.wiki_summary: SWT may refer to: Scottish Wildlife Trust, a charity in Scotland Subhanahu wa ta'ala, Arabic for "The most glorified, the most high", Muslim honorific Stationary wavelet transform Standard Widget Toolkit, a graphical widget toolkit for use with the Java platform Slaithwaite railway station, England; National Rail station code South West Trains, a former train operating company in southern England

Holy Places.wiki_summary: A holy place is a place that people consider holy and/or a religion considers to be of special religious significance.

Seerah.wiki_summary: In Islam, Al-sīra al-Nabawiyya (Prophetic biography), Sīrat Rasūl Allāh (Life of the Messenger of God), or Seerah are the traditional Muslim biographies of Muhammad from which, in addition to the Quran and trustable Hadiths, most historical information about his life and the early period of Islam is derived.

Makka.wiki_summary: Mecca, also spelled Makkah, is a city in the Hejazi region of Saudi Arabia.

Kuffar.wiki_summary: Kafir (Arabic: كافر‎ kāfir; plural كَافِرُونَ kāfirūna, كفّار kuffār or كَفَرَة kafarah; feminine كافرة kāfirah; feminine plural كافرات kāfirāt or كوافر kawāfir) is an Arabic term (from the root K-F-R "to cover") meaning "infidel", "rejector", "disbeliever", "unbeliever", "nonbeliever".

Kaferoon.wiki_summary: Kafir (Arabic: كافر‎ kāfir; plural كَافِرُونَ kāfirūna, كفّار kuffār or كَفَرَة kafarah; feminine كافرة kāfirah; feminine plural كافرات kāfirāt or كوافر kawāfir) is an Arabic term (from the root K-F-R "to cover") meaning "infidel",[1] "rejector",[2] "disbeliever", "unbeliever", "nonbeliever".

Hubal.wiki_summary: Hubal (Arabic: هُبَل‎) was a god worshipped in pre-Islamic Arabia, notably by Quraysh at the Kaaba in Mecca.

Arabian.wiki_summary: The Arabian Peninsula, or simply Arabia (; Arabic:

Torah.wiki_summary: It can most specifically mean the first five books (Pentateuch or five books of Moses) of the 24 books of the Tanakh (Hebrew Bible)

Prophets.wiki_summary: In religion, a prophet is an individual who is regarded as being in contact with a divine being and is said to speak on that entity's behalf, serving as an intermediary with humanity by delivering messages or teachings from the supernatural source to other people.

Shariah.wiki_summary: Sharia (, Arabic: شريعة‎ [ʃaˈriːʕa]), Islamic law or sharia law is a religious law forming part of the Islamic tradition.

Quran.wiki_summary: The Quran ( kor-AHN; Arabic: القرآن‎, romanized: al-Qurʼān Arabic pronunciation: [alqur'ʔaːn], literally meaning "the recitation"), also romanized Qur'an or Koran, is the central religious text of Islam, which Muslims believe to be a revelation from God (Allah).

Divine.wiki_summary: In religion, divinity or Godhead is the state of things that are believed to come from a supernatural power or deity, such as God, the supreme being, creator deity, or spirits, and are therefore regarded as sacred and holy.

Usury.wiki_summary: Usury () is the practice of making unethical or immoral monetary loans that unfairly enrich the lender.

Qunduz.wiki_summary: Kunduz or Qunduz (Persian: قندوز‎, Pashto: کندوز‎) is one of the 34 provinces of Afghanistan, located in the northern part of the country next to Tajikistan.

Crusades.wiki_summary: The crusades were a series of religious wars in western Asia and Europe initiated, supported and sometimes directed by the Roman Catholic Church between the 11th and the 17th century.

Time.wiki_summary: Time is the indefinite continued progress of existence and events that occur in an apparently irreversible succession from the past, through the present, to the future.

Halliburton.wiki_summary: Halliburton Company is an American multinational corporation.

Guardian.wiki_summary: Guardian may refer to: Legal guardian, a person with the authority and duty to care for the interests of anotherGuardian(s) or The Guardian(s) may also refer to:

Guidance.wiki_summary: Guidance may refer to: What a guide gives Guidance (album), by American instrumental rock band Russian Circles
